awd_titl_txt: ATD: Algorithms for Anomaly Detection Using Graphical Models
awd_abstract_narration:
The increased connectivity of our physical and virtual environments results in elevated risks from agents who utilize interconnectedness in order to spread and communicate. The PI will develop a mathematical methodology and algorithms to detect corrupt agents / elements in interconnected and dynamically changing environments.  Potential applications include the detection of corrupt agents in governmental and financial networks as well as detection of anomalies in electrical networks, chemical plants and other physical infrastructure and detection of election tampering. 

The common theme of the project is studying systems whose states are defined by graphs and where the detection of an anomaly is based on graph properties and graph algorithms. The PI will study corruption detection on a graph where nodes represent entities that can examine the status of their neighbors. Which graphs and which algorithms are efficient at recovering corrupt nodes if such exist? In a different direction, the PI will utilize Markov Random Fields as models representing the interaction between individuals with the goal of detecting anomalies from a dynamic perspective.  The PI will further study new notions of anomalies in voting, where the PI will utilize the mathematical tools from the theories of noise stability and isoperimetry to define and detect unlikely voting configurations.

por.por_cntn:
The project studies the problem of corruption detection in networks where nodes test or audit their neighbors in the network. It uses and develops the theory of expander graphs to show that such graphs allow efficient detection of corruption in networks, even if corruption is widespread. Furthermore, for general (non-expander) networks 

it studied the algorithmic complexity of the problem of finding corrupt nodes and the algorithmic complexity of hiding corrupt nodes. 

 

In a different direction, the project studies the inference of statistical models called graphical models. Such models are parametrized by networks. The project studies the problem of inference of such networks in a setting where some elements of the networks cannot be reached and their data is unavailable.  Inspired by statistical physics dynamics, the project develops algorithms to perform inference on such networks provided far away elements of the networks exhibit only a weak correlation.

On the other hand, computational barriers to perform the inference are established if long range correlations are present. 

 

A third direction of the proposal studies property testing of functions. Here the goal is to test how far a function that is given in a black-box fashion from a family of simple functions. This can be used to efficiently test anomalies in given functions. 

The challenge is that the testing algorithm can only use very few data points. In particular, the number of data points should not depend on the dimension of the data. Using new ideas from discrete Fourier analysis, efficient algorithms are developed that solve the problem for a wide class of functions in both discrete and continuous settings.  

 

  All of the work was carried out by the PI with collaborators, post-doctoral fellows and graduate students who were partially supported by the grant in their professional development.
